meanings.definition: A person who harrows or distresses others.
meanings.sent1: The harrowers in the story made the main character very sad.
meanings.sent2: The harrowers in the neighborhood were known for their unkind words.
meanings.sent3: The harrowers at the party kept teasing everyone in a mean way.
meanings.sent4: The harrowers of the mind can sometimes be more painful than physical pain.
meanings.sent5: The harrowers of the soul left deep emotional scars on the protagonist.

meanings.definition: Those who cause torment or suffering.
meanings.sent1: The harrowers of the village were feared by all for their cruel actions.
meanings.sent2: The harrowers of the forest were said to bring misfortune to those who crossed their path.
meanings.sent3: The harrowers in the movie were portrayed as villains who enjoyed causing pain.
meanings.sent4: The harrowers of the heart can make life feel unbearable at times.
meanings.sent5: The harrowers of the spirit drained all hope from the weary travelers.

meanings.definition: Individuals who cause anguish or grief.
meanings.sent1: The harrowers of the school playground were bullies who made others feel miserable.
meanings.sent2: The harrowers of the workplace created a toxic environment for their colleagues.
meanings.sent3: The harrowers in the play were comically exaggerated, making the audience laugh.
meanings.sent4: The harrowers of the past haunted her dreams with their haunting presence.
meanings.sent5: The harrowers of the mind whispered doubts and fears into her thoughts.
